attributes.alt: Book cover for Lola Plants a Garden by Anna McQuinn and illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw. The cover art shows a girl on her stomach in the grass with her head propped on her hands. She is looking at her newly planted garden and smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build math background, engage children with a nursery rhyme, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking,
What is one thing Lola puts in her garden?
Read interactively for enjoyment, with a focus on operations.
Use informal strategies to separate up to 10 objects into two equal sets.
Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Try to help others make things better or easier.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Use subject-verb agreement; Use regular and irregular plurals; Use pronouns; Use possessives.
Ask children to plant equal numbers of Connecting Cubes in two areas of a “garden.”
Guide children to count “seeds” in various orders to demonstrate that the count remains the same.
How can we help plants grow?
What plant would you like to read about?
Pretend to be a gardener. What is something that gardeners do?
How many flowers you would like in your garden? Can you count them out?
Draw a picture of a flower. How many petals does it have?
What sound do you hear at the beginning of the word
Build a garden where your plants can grow big and strong!

attributes.alt: Book cover for Lola Plants a Garden by Anna McQuinn and illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw. The cover art shows a girl on her stomach in the grass with her head propped on her hands. She is looking at her newly planted garden and smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the Mind Builder
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely to talk about how characters help each other and to identify patterns.
Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns.

Count aloud 1–10 items with one-to-one correspondence; Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set; Count the same number of different items to see that the quantity is the same even when the objects are different.
Use pretend money during play, earning money for work, and using money to buy goods and services.
Try to help others make things better or easier.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Use digital tools and resources safely.
Have children make a plan for a garden using Pattern Blocks.
Guide children to count five blocks of each color and create an ABAB pattern.
Discuss ways to show caring for others.
How can we help plants grow?
Is there a plant in this book?
Pretend to give a flower to someone you love.
Use play money to pretend to buy a gift for someone’s birthday.
Write about something nice you’ve done for someone.
Draw two different flowers. How would you plant them?
What two letters does the word
start with? Can you show me how to write them?
Build a fence for your garden.

attributes.alt: Book cover for Lola Plants a Garden by Anna McQuinn and illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw. The cover art shows a girl on her stomach in the grass with her head propped on her hands. She is looking at her newly planted garden and smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share a measurement strategy, engage children with a size hunt, and introduce vocabulary
What is one thing Lola does to care for her garden?
Read interactively for deeper comprehension and to review measurement.
Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long.
Use fingers, objects, or drawings to show a verbal word problem adding to or subtracting from a set of up to five objects.
Try to help others make things better or easier.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Ask children to “plant” a certain amount of Connecting Cubes.
Guide children to add and subtract to find how many “seeds” are left to plant.
How can we help plants grow?
Do you like reading books about plants? Why do you say that?
Pretend to be a gardener. What are you planting? Why?
How can you use Connecting Cubes to measure this object’s height?
Write a story about a very tall flower.
Why did you choose those colors to draw your flower?
What sound do you hear at the end of the word
? Can you write the letter that makes that sound?
Could you build a garden with tall flowers and short flowers using those materials?

attributes.alt: Big Chart of Big Ideas for Jack and the Beanstalk. The chart says, Jack traded their cow for the beans; Jack climbed and climbed; Jack saved the goose; Down, down, down Jack went.

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas:  Jack and the Beanstalk

attributes.alt: Book cover for Lola Plants a Garden by Anna McQuinn and illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw. The cover art shows a girl on her stomach in the grass with her head propped on her hands. She is looking at her newly planted garden and smiling.

elements.text: Big Book: Lola Plants a Garden
Use Circle Time to engage children with a game and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read interactively and connect to measurement by comparing the heights of items and characters in the Big Chart.

Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long”; Use pretend money during play, earning money for work, and using money to buy goods and services.
Recognize, complete, extend, duplicate, and create common patterns.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set.
Try to help others make things better or easier.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Ask children to build “beanstalks” using Connecting Cubes to create repeating patterns.
Guide children to measure and compare their beanstalks using Connecting Cubes as units of measurement.
How can we help plants grow?
What do you think about the plants in that book?
Pretend to be a giant. Are you taller than a tree?
Use the play money to pretend to buy beans for a beanstalk.
Would you rather plant a garden like Lola or a beanstalk like Jack? Write about why.
Can you draw a beanstalk that is taller than a house?
Can you look around the room and find something that starts with the same sound as
Build a few houses. Can you put them in order from shortest to tallest?

attributes.alt: Book cover for Lola Plants a Garden by Anna McQuinn and illustrated by Rosalind Beardshaw. The cover art shows a girl on her stomach in the grass with her head propped on her hands. She is looking at her newly planted garden and smiling.

elements.text: Use Circle Time to connect to language and act out a garden scene.
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking,
What steps can you take to plant and care for a garden?
Read and retell interactively for physical engagement and to count items in the book.
Measure, describe, and compare height and length of objects using like units and words like “small,” “big,” “short,” “tall,” and “long.
Use the last number counted to tell “how many” are in a set; Understand that the order in which items are arranged or counted does not affect the total count.
Try to help others make things better or easier.
Use regular and irregular past tense.
Observe, investigate, describe, and talk about common objects.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s prompt:
How would you decorate your own garden?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
How can we help plants grow?
What kind of book would you like to read next?
Pretend to be a scientist who studies plants. What plant are you studying?
Imagine a flower that no one has ever seen. How tall is it? How many petals does it have?
Write a story about a gardener who finds a new kind of flower.
Imagine a new type of flower. What will you use to create it?
Choose a name for your new flower. What letter does it start with?
Build a garden for a flower no one has ever seen before.

Use informal strategies to separate up to 10 items into equal groups.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Use regular and irregular plurals, regular past tense, personal and possessive pronouns, and subject-verb agreement.
Make inferences and predictions about text.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Count 1–10 items, with one count per item.
Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Make inferences and predictions about a text.
Observe, investigate, describe, and discuss properties and characteristics of common objects.
Practice safe behavior while using digital tools and resources.
Use concrete objects, create pictorial models, and share a verbal word problem for adding up to five objects.
Use concrete models or make a verbal word problem for subtracting 0–5 objects from a set.
Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Make inferences and predictions about text.

Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.

Count up to 10 items and demonstrate that the last count indicates how many items were counted.

Recognize and compare heights or lengths of people or objects.
Demonstrate empathy and caring for others.
Independently write to communicate ideas for a variety of purposes.
